worksheet.title: Column, row, and null spaces

statement.p:
Think of an m\times 3 matrix A as being made out of three column vectors from \R^m:
A = \begin{bmatrix} | \amp | \amp | \\ \uvec{c}_1 \amp \uvec{c}_2 \amp \uvec{c}_3 \\ | \amp | \amp | \end{bmatrix}.
Do you remember what happens when we compute A\uvec{e}_1? A\uvec{e}_2? A\uvec{e}_3? Recall
\uvec{e}_i represents the \nth[i] standard basis vector in \R^n. In this instance, we are considering it as a column vector.
Suppose we want to compute A\uvec{x}, where \uvec{x} = (5,3,-1) (but as a column vector). Use what you remembered in the previous part of this activity to fill in the following.
Since
\left[\begin{array}{r} 5 \\ 3 \\ -1 \end{array}\right] \amp = 5\uvec{e}_1 + 3\uvec{e}_2 + (-1)\uvec{e}_3,
then
A\left[\begin{smallmatrix} 5 \\ 3 \\ -1 \end{smallmatrix}\right] \amp = 5 + 3 + (-1).
From this, we see that the column vector A\uvec{x} is in the span of .
Convince yourself that the details/conclusion of the previous part of this activity would be the same for every \uvec{x}, not just the example \uvec{x} we used.
Now consider system A\uvec{x}=\uvec{b}. If this system is consistent ( has at least one solution), then our final conclusion from the second part of this activity would also be true about the column vector \uvec{b}, since \uvec{b} = A\uvec{x} for at least one \uvec{x}.
So system A\uvec{x} = \uvec{b} can only be consistent if \uvec{b} is in the span of .

prelude.p: For m\times n matrix A, from it appears that the subspace of \R^m obtained by taking the span of the columns of A is important when considering consistency of the system A\uvec{x} = \uvec{b}. Call this subspace the column space of Acolumnspacematrixcolumn space. Let's explore how to reduce our spanning set (the columns of A) down to a basis. For this task we'll need a fact about how multiplication by a matrix affects the linear independence of column vectors.

statement.p: Suppose \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_\ell are column vectors in \R^n and E is an m\times n matrix. If vectors E\uvec{v}_1,E\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,E\uvec{v}_\ell are linearly independent in \R^m, then so too \uvec{v}_1,\uvec{v}_2,\dotsc,\uvec{v}_\ell are linearly independent in \R^n.

The following matrix is in RREF:
B = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp 5 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 4 \amp 0 \amp 6 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 7 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}.
Build a linearly independent set of column vectors from B by working from left to right, and either including or discarding each column based on whether it is linearly independent from the vectors you have already accumulated. (You should, of course, begin by including the first column.) What do you notice about your final set of linearly independent columns, relative to the reduced form of B?
Suppose A is a matrix that can be reduced to B by a single elementary operation. Then there is an elementary matrix E so that
B = EA = \begin{bmatrix} | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp |\\ E\uvec{c}_1 \amp E\uvec{c}_2 \amp E\uvec{c}_3 \amp E\uvec{c}_4 \amp E\uvec{c}_5 \amp E\uvec{c}_6 \\ | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \end{bmatrix},
where the \uvec{c}_j are the columns of A. Use part (a) and the proposition stated above to determine which columns of A form a linearly independent set.
Now suppose A is a matrix that can be reduced to B by two elementary operations. Then there are elementary matrices E_1,E_2 so that B = E_2E_1A. Similarly to part (b), from B = E_2(E_1A), decide which columns of E_1A are linearly independent. Then from the proposition stated above and
E_1A = \begin{bmatrix} | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp |\\ E_1\uvec{c}_1 \amp E_1\uvec{c}_2 \amp E_1\uvec{c}_3 \amp E_1\uvec{c}_4 \amp E_1\uvec{c}_5 \amp E_1\uvec{c}_6 \\ | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \amp | \end{bmatrix}
(where the \uvec{c}_j are the columns of A), decide which columns of A are linearly independent.
Now extrapolate to any number of row operations to complete the following statement: to create a linearly independent set of column vectors from a matrix A, row reduce A to RREF, and then take those columns of A that correspond to in \operatorname{RREF}(A).

worksheet.p: Why let the columns of a matrix have all the fun? Let's now explore the subspace of \R^n formed by the span of the rows in an m\times n matrix, called the row space rowspace matrixrow space of the matrix.

prelude.p: In the next activity, we'll need the following fact that gives us a way to determine when two spans are the same. You should re-read that statement before proceeding.

statement.p: If each vector in S can be expressed as a linear combination of the vectors in S', and each vector in S' can be expressed as a linear combination of the vectors in S, then \Span S and \Span S' are the same space.

Determine a basis for the row space of a matrix A for which
\RREF(A) = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 3\\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 4 \amp 0 \amp 5\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 6\\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{bmatrix}.

statement.p: If you have a collection of vectors in \R^n and you want to obtain a basis for the subspace that the collection spans, you now have two options: either use those vectors as the columns in a matrix and row reduce to determine a basis for its column space, or use those vectors as the rows in a matrix and row reduce to determine a basis for its row space. Can you think of a reason you might choose to use column space instead of row space? And a reason you might choose to use row space instead of column space?

worksheet.p: There is one more subspace of \R^n associated to a matrix A the solution space of the homogeneous system A\uvec{x}=\zerovec. Instead of solution space, from this point forward we will refer to it as the null space nullspace matrixnull space of A.

aside.p: The Subspace Test can be used to show that the solution set of a homogeneous system with a m\times n coefficient matrix is a subspace of \R^n.

statement.p:
Suppose A is a matrix whose RREF is as given below. Use the independent parameter method to determine a basis for the null space of A.
\RREF(A) = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrr} 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 2 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp -2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right]
